definition: Wang Dun (266-324), powerful general of Jin dynasty and brother of civil official Wang Dao 王導|王导, subsequently rebellious warlord 322-324
king or monarch/best or strongest of its type/grand/great
surname Wang
to rule/to reign over
kindhearted/place name

sentences.english: Wang, don't buy it, he originally was able to drink, but hard twist slant not to drink.
sentences.chinese: 王敦卻不買賬，他原本倒是能喝酒，卻硬拗着偏不喝。

definition: Sima Zhao (211-265), military general and statesman of Cao Wei 曹魏[Cao2 Wei4]
Fu Jian (338-385), emperor of Former Qin 前秦[Qian2 Qin2], reigning from 357-385
Huan Xuan (369-404), general involved in the break-up of Eastern Jin
Liu Biao (142-208), warlord
Wang Dao (276-339), powerful official of Jin dynasty and brother of general Wang Dun 王敦, regent of Jin from 325
Sun Quan (reigned 222-252), southern warlord and king of state of Wu 吳|吴 in the Three Kingdoms period
Sima Yan (236-290), founding emperor of Jin dynasty 晋 after the Three Kingdoms period, reigned 265-290 as Emperor Wu of Jin 晉武帝
Yuan Shao (153-202), general during late Han, subsequently warlord
Cao Pi (187-226), second son of Cao Cao 曹操, king then emperor of Cao Wei 曹魏 from 220, ruled as Emperor Wen 魏文帝, also a noted calligrapher
Liu Yu, founder of Song of the Southern dynasties 劉宋|刘宋[Liu2 Song4], broke away from Eastern Jin in 420, reigned as Emperor Wu of Song 宋武帝[Song4 Wu3 di4]
Dong Zhuo (-192), top general of late Han, usurped power in 189, murdered empress dowager and child emperor, killed in 192 by Lü Bu 呂布|吕布

Zhu Wen (852-912), military governor 節度使|节度使[jie2 du4 shi3] at the end of Tang, founder of Later Liang of the Five Dynasties (907-923), also known as Emperor Taizu of Later Liang 後梁太祖|后梁太祖[Hou4 Liang2 Tai4 zu3]
Cao Wei, the most powerful of the Three Kingdoms, established as a dynasty in 220 by Cao Pi 曹丕, son of Cao Cao, replaced by Jin dynasty in 265
Eastern Wu (222-280)/the southern state of Wu during the Three Kingdoms period, founded by Sun Quan 孫權|孙权
Xun Yu (163-212), brilliant strategist, advisor of Cao Cao in Three Kingdoms
Shi Le, founder of Later Zhao of the Sixteen Kingdoms 後趙|后赵 (319-350)
